description: From Middle English lyme, lym, lime, from Old English līm, from Proto-Germanic *līmaz, from Proto-Indo-European *sley- (“smooth; slick; sticky; slimy”).
Cognate with Saterland Frisian Liem (“glue”), Dutch lijm, German Leim (“glue”), Danish lim (from Old Norse lím), Latin limus (“mud”).

entries.meaning: (chemistry) Any inorganic material containing calcium, usually calcium oxide (quicklime) or calcium hydroxide (slaked lime).
examples: Lime, which is the product of the burning of chalk or limestone, might be bought ready burnt, or it could be burnt in kilns specially constructed in the neighbourhood of the building operations.

entries.meaning: (poetic) Any gluey or adhesive substance; something which traps or captures someone; sometimes a synonym for birdlime.
examples: Like the lime which foolish birds are caught with.
Sellers moved on until he was actually trusted to operate the limes, the spotlights that can make or destroy an artist's act.

verbs.description: lime (third-person singular simple present limes, present participle liming, simple past and past participle limed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To treat with calcium hydroxide or calcium oxide (lime).
examples: If I were you, I'd lime.

description: Lime (17th c.) and line (16th c.) are alterations of obsolete lind, from Middle English lynde, from Old English lind, from Proto-Germanic *lindijō. The phonetic development is unusual, but it has been suggested that it began in compounds (loss of -d- perhaps before tree, the change to -m- before labials as in bark or wood). Doublet of linden, which see.

entries.meaning: A deciduous tree of the genus Tilia, especially Tilia × europaea; the linden tree.

description: From French lime, from Spanish lima, from Arabic لِيمَة‎ (līma), from Persian لیمو‎ (limu). Doublet of lemon.

entries.meaning: Having the aroma or flavor of lime.
Any of several green citrus fruit, somewhat smaller and sharper-tasting than a lemon.
Any of the trees that bear limes, especially Key lime, Citrus aurantiifolia.
(uncountable) A brilliant, sometimes yellowish, green colour associated with the fruits of a lime tree.
(fandom slang) A fan fiction story which contains sexual references, but stops short of full, explicit descriptions of sexual activity (coined by analogy with lemon).
(Caribbean, Trinidad & Tobago) A casual gathering to socialize.

verbs.description: lime (third-person singular simple present limes, present participle liming, simple past and past participle limed)

entries.meaning: (Caribbean, Trinidad & Tobago) To hang out/socialize in an informal, relaxed environment, especially with friends, for example at a party or on the beach.
